topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Adriel Frederick (Reddit, Lyft, Facebook) and previews themes like growth, diversity, and AI. Adriel gives a fast career overview from Trinidad to consulting to tech roles across Intuit, Facebook, biotech, and Lyft.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Linear and Flatfile, focused on issue tracking workflows and CSV/data onboarding during B2B onboarding.

topics.title: Reddit X and new interaction modes
topics.summary: Adriel explains Reddit X as an incubation team exploring new modes of interaction on Reddit (audience, temporality, media like video/audio) rather than metaverse bets. He shares an example: the Reddit avatar marketplace using NFT tech for creator rights and IP acknowledgement.

topics.title: How to run R&D teams without rejection
topics.summary: Adriel describes “organ rejection” risks for R&D/incubation groups and how to avoid them: tie work to core mission, make wins shared across the company, and avoid signaling that only the R&D team gets to innovate.

topics.title: Trinidad background shaping product assumptions
topics.summary: Adriel explains how growing up in Trinidad’s diverse environment shaped his worldview and product instincts. He gives a concrete example: challenging the common tech assumption that one phone number/device maps to one person, influencing Facebook registration and growth design.

topics.title: Building diversity for speed and retention
topics.summary: Adriel shares what it was like being Facebook’s first Black PM and how diverse teams improved product decision speed by bringing global user perspectives into the room. He argues diversity efforts work best when leaders see clear business value, build a culture that retains diverse talent, and then recruiting becomes easier.

topics.title: Leading amid controversy and bad press
topics.summary: Adriel discusses working at high-scrutiny companies (Facebook, Lyft, Reddit) and the PM’s role as a stabilizing force—damping extremes of hype or criticism. He emphasizes separating valid critiques from power-shift backlash by staying close to users, including personally driving for Lyft to understand driver economics and rider needs.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Eppo, an A/B testing and experimentation platform for modern growth teams, highlighting slicing results and using north-star metrics.

topics.title: Lyft pricing failure and operational control
topics.summary: Adriel recounts a stressful Lyft moment: launching a complex pricing model that became hard to operate and change, forcing a rebuild. The key lesson: operational requirements and human-in-the-loop control must be first-order design constraints in marketplace products.

topics.title: Humans and algorithms: tools, judgment, interfaces
topics.summary: Adriel generalizes the lesson: algorithms optimize objectives but don’t understand intent, long-term effects, or strategic constraints, so PMs must define what humans decide vs machines execute. He frames ML as a tool that should amplify human intent via good interfaces, not operate as an unchecked black box; they discuss AI risk/exponential progress briefly.

topics.title: Growth hacking myths and real growth work
topics.summary: Adriel critiques “growth hacks” as insufficient without real user value and warns against treating users as easily fooled. He describes Facebook growth as grinding fundamentals—discoverability, onboarding, and especially helping users find friends—plus a concrete insight about friend recommendations spiraling into one friend group and needing broader seeding.
